Situation1: They occasionally tidy up visible clutter and do light cleaning in shared spaces.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: A casual conversation drifts toward personal topics but nothing particularly sensitive is mentioned.
Story:
I was wiping down the kitchen counters, my mind half on the crumbs and half on the conversation drifting from the living room. As a housekeeping cleaner, I was expected to keep the house spotless, but lately, I’d only had time for the basics—tidying up the obvious messes, running a cloth over surfaces, and making sure the shared spaces looked presentable. Today, while I worked, one of the residents started chatting with me. It was friendly, nothing too deep, but as a volunteer, I knew I was supposed to respect their privacy and keep anything I heard confidential.

But as I picked up a stack of magazines, I noticed a note with a name and phone number on it, left out in the open. My cleaner’s instinct told me to organize it, maybe even mention it to the resident so it wouldn’t get lost. But the volunteer in me hesitated—was it really my place to point it out, or should I pretend I hadn’t seen it? The expectations of both roles pressed in on me: keep things tidy, but don’t intrude. I stood there, cloth in hand, torn between what I should do next.
